thread.title: WIAA girls tennis - Czerwonka outlasts rival for Division 2 singles title
thread.title_full: WIAA girls tennis - Czerwonka outlasts rival for Division 2 singles title

author: Tamira Madsen
title: WIAA girls tennis - Czerwonka outlasts rival for Division 2 singles title
text:
Madison â€” Claire Czerwonka and Tallie Piaskowski have split four matches in two seasons, but Czerwonka of Kenosha St. Joseph has claimed the two that matter most.
Czerwonka clinched her second straight Division 2 singles title against her Manitowoc Roncalli rival on Saturday with a 7-6 (2), 7-6 (6) victory in the WIAA girls state individual tennis tournament at the Nielsen Tennis Stadium.
Piaskowski, the top seed, roared back from a 1-5 first-set deficit to frustrate Czerwonka, and continued to pose challenges in the second. Czerwonka said the match was the toughest she's played in high school.
"It was a fight; the whole entire thing was a battle," Czerwonka said. "I think the difference was I had a little bit extra to go and pushed myself a little more. I nailed my shots and wanted it so bad. She played amazing, too."
Piaskowski, who also finished third at state in 2013, had strung together wins against Czerwonka during the regular season. At the state tournament, it has been a different story, but the senior said Saturday's championship came down to a few points and consistency.
"It couldn't have been any closer," Piaskowski said. "There wasn't much more I could have done; she outplayed me. It was a good, close match."
The Fitbit fitness tracker wrapped around Czerwonka's wrist lost power at 30,000-plus steps after the junior's 2-6, 7-6 (8), 6-2 win over Veda Sane, a University School freshman, in the semifinals on Saturday morning.
But outlasting Piaskowski was the ultimate goal for Czerwonka, the tournament's No. 2 seed who finished the season with a 28-1 record.
"I had to focus and I just had to think one more point, one more point," Czerwonka said.
In Division 1 singles, Stevens Point junior Emily Luetschwager ousted Dao Sysouvanh of Sun Prairie, 6-2, 6-4, to take home the state championship and maintain an undefeated season with a 34-0 record. Luetschwager dispatched Homestead's Katya Mikhailenko earlier Saturday in the semifinals, 6-2, 6-2.
Meanwhile, the top podium spots in state doubles showcased the transformation and success of competitors with singles backgrounds.
Riley Strauss and Caroline Taylor of University School clinched the Division 2 doubles title with a 6-1, 7-5 victory over Madison Edgewood's Abby Fox and Maddie Molitor.
Taylor realized she would move down the Wildcats singles ladder due to Sane's talents, and said she switched to doubles to "play higher" during her senior year. Partnering with Strauss, a sophomore, was a no-brainer since the teammates share a similar work ethic.
"We put in the extra time," Taylor said. "We played after practice, we played with other coaches and we set up matches with guys from other high schools. That definitely helped us."
University School coach Andy Paley said watching the pair learn the rhythm and movement of doubles during the course of the season has been an interesting experience. Being able to adapt to momentum shifts in matches has been critical to their success.
"They both love to fight," Paley said. "Caroline is a hacker at the net and Riley, being a lefty with her serve and her ground strokes, they put the package together. They always try to change the rhythm and never try to be predictable."
In Division 1 doubles, Abbey Webber and Kaisey Skibba of Middleton bested Nicolet's Elise Gerard and Annabelle Crowley, 6-1, 6-1, to earn the state championship.
Skibba, who was a state qualifier for three years at singles, was competing in doubles for the first time. Gerard, a Nicolet junior, made the move after two seasons, and hopes to be partnered with Crowley, who is a freshman, again next year.
Despite the title loss, Gerard said she walked away from state with a positive experience.
"They knew everything we were going to do and were just so smart," Gerard said of Webber and Skibba. "We were the (No.) four seed, and I'm really happy we got to the finals."
RESULTS DIVISION 1 Championship singles Emily Luetschwager, Stevens Point, def. Dao Sysouvanh, Sun Praire, 6-2, 6-4.
Semifinal singles Emily Luetschwager, Stevens Point, def. Katya Mikhailenko, HOM.
Dao Sysouvanh, Sun Praire, def. Kiki Risgaard, Neenah, 6-1, 6-2.
Championship doubles Abbey Webber/Kaisey Kibba, Middleton, def. Elise Gerard/Annabell Crowley, Nicolet, 6-1, 6-1.
Semifinal doubles Abbey Webber/Kaisey Kibba, Middleton, def. Emily Pepperl/Devon Bourget, Eau Claire Memorial, 1-6, 6-4, 6-4.
Elise Gerard/Annabell Crowley, Nicolet, def. Sara Geschke/Kali Flesch, Arrowhead, 7-5, 6-3.
DIVISION 2 Championship singles Claire Czerwonka, Kenosha St. Joesph, def. Tallie Piaskowski, Roncalli, 7-6(2), 7-6(5).
Semifinal singles Claire Czerwonka, Kenosha St. Joesph, def. Veda Sane, University School, 2-6, 7-6(8), 6-2.
Tallie Piaskowski, Roncalli, def. Emma Sango, Edgewood Sacred Heart, 6-1, 6-2.
Championship doubles Riley Strauss/Caroline Taylor, University School, def. Abby Fox/Maddie Molitor, Edgewood Sacred Heart, 6-1, 7-5.
Semifinal doubles Riley Strauss/Caroline Taylor, University School, def. Grace Gould/Emilie Mettraux, Racine Prarie, 6-2, 6-4.
Abby Fox/Maddie Molitor, Edgewood Sacred Heart, def. Megan Jacobson/Hanna Zevenbergen, Baldwin-Woodville, 6-0, 6-1.
